awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Constraining Parton Distribution Functions for New-Physics Searches
awd_abstract_narration:
This project concerns physics at the femtoscale (a million times smaller than the nanoscale) within nucleons, the fundamental building blocks of the atomic nuclei. As ever improving precision in experiments puts theories to more stringent tests, highly accurate theoretical calculations are required to advance our understanding of the nucleon structure. In this context, this project will contribute precise numerical calculations of nucleon properties in support of the experimental programs at state-of-the-art experimental facilities, such as the Brookhaven and Jefferson Laboratories in the United States, GSI in Germany, and J-PARC in Japan.  This research involves the development of high-performance computational methods and large-scale numerical calculations on supercomputers. This project provides excellent training opportunities for students on both theoretical and numerical methods. 
 
This project aims to improve the systematic uncertainties in lattice-QCD (LQCD) determinations of the parton distribution functions (PDFs), to leverage these results to reduce uncertainties in global PDF fits, and to use them to provide more precise Standard-Model inputs to aid new-physics searches and guide upcoming QCD-frontier research. In high-energy physics, PDF uncertainty is the dominant error in the theoretical input to quantities such as the Higgs-production cross section. In nuclear physics, investment at RHIC and JLab 12-GeV has been made to explore the sea-quark and gluon structure of nucleons. The PI made the first LQCD calculation of the Bjorken-x dependence of the PDFs using the "large-momentum effective theory" method. The latter is expected to open new doors of opportunity to the study of multidimensional proton structure, such as generalized parton distributions (GPDs) and transverse-momentum distributions (TMDs). By the end of the award period, the PI will work with the global PDF analysis community to incorporate LQCD results, producing fits with the improved precision needed for new-physics searches at LHC and to make predictions for upcoming measurements at current nuclear laboratories and the future EIC.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF CAREER Award "CAREER: Constraining Parton Distribution Functions for New-Physics Searches" has made significant contributions to theoretical physics, advancing our understanding of particle properties. The project has focused on the quantum chromodynamics (QCD) and parton distribution functions (PDFs), conducting pioneering calculations and providing new insights into these topics. Below are selected key accomplishments.

Intellectual Merit

  • Progress on nucleon isovector PDF-related calculations: The project has constrained global-analysis fits of experimental data by using lattice-averaged isovector tensor-charge (gT) calculations, improving our knowledge of transversity for transverse-momentum-dependent PDFs (TMDs) and fragmentation functions. These advancements provide better predictions for high-x transversity, which will be measured soon from US-based experiments.

  • First x-dependent meson distribution amplitudes (DAs): The project has calculated x-dependent quark DAs of pions and kaons, using the Large-Momentum Effective Theory (LaMET) approach. This work has explored the pion-mass dependence of distribution amplitudes and provided insight into the variation of DA shapes with quark mass. This is also the first x-dependent distribution that implements machine learning. These findings enhance our understanding of meson properties.

  • First gluon PDFs of nucleons and pions: The project initiated exploratory studies on gluon PDFs within the lattice-QCD framework. These calculations were conducted with high statistics and showed compatibility with global fits, providing valuable insights into gluon distribution functions. Additionally, the project extended these calculations to gluon quasi-PDFs in pions, opening new avenues for understanding gluon properties in hadrons. Lattice calculation of the gluon PDFs show great potential to provide better gluon PDFs than global fits. 

  • First x-dependent valence-quark pion and kaon PDFs: The project has been at the forefront of lattice-QCD studies, offering the first insights into the x dependence of valence-quark PDFs for pions and kaons. These findings, with calculations at multiple pion masses, lattice spacings, and high statistics, have expanded our knowledge of quark distribution functions in these mesons. Predictions for up and strange content of the kaon were made for the first time using lattice QCD.

  • First lattice x-dependent strange and charm PDFs: The project has contributed to the calculation of x-dependent strange and charm parton distributions, revealing the relationship between quark-antiquark distribution asymmetry and the strange and charm contributions. These findings support the assumptions made in global-fit PDF analyses and highlight the importance of higher statistics for further constraints.

  • First lattice x-dependent GPDs and nucleon tomography: The project advanced the understanding of Generalized Parton Distributions (GPDs) by providing x-dependent valence-quark GPDs for pions and nucleons. This work has also introduced nucleon tomography using lattice QCD, allowing for a deeper exploration of parton distribution properties.

Broader Impact

The project has also demonstrated a significant broader impact by:

  • Creating a QCD phone game, "Quantum 3," aimed at making QCD accessible to children and the general public. The game's design, inspired by Match-3 games, makes learning about complex physics concepts engaging and fun, encouraging early exposure to QCD.

  • Volunteering at multiple outreach events like Physics and Astronomy Day and the MSU Science Festival, reaching a broad audience and promoting STEM fields.

  • Mentorship of undergraduate students in research, breaking down complex tasks into accessible portions and helping them understand the field of LQCD. This engagement led to valuable research contributions, publications, and fellowships for the participating students, ultimately enhancing their academic and research prospects.

Conclusion

The NSF CAREER Award "CAREER: Constraining Parton Distribution Functions for New-Physics Searches" has made significant contributions to theoretical physics, QCD, PDF calculations, and broader outreach efforts. The project's intellectual merit lies in the advancement of our understanding of fundamental particle properties, while its broader impact is seen in educational outreach and the mentorship of undergraduate students in research. The project's positive outcomes benefit the scientific community and aspiring physicists alike.
